question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Be sure to provide executable code for demonstration. Create an HTML code for teaching the periodic table of elements for middle school chemistry.

checklist.title: Is the periodic table structure fully implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the HTML code correctly represents the standard periodic table layout with all 118 elements positioned in their correct groups and periods. Check if the table maintains proper spacing and alignment between elements. Score 0 if elements are missing or misplaced, 5 if the basic structure is implemented but with minor positioning errors, and 10 if the periodic table structure is complete and accurately arranged.

checklist.title: Are the element details comprehensive and educationally appropriate?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether each element includes essential information for middle school education: atomic number, symbol, name, atomic weight, and electron configuration. Check if information is presented in a clear hierarchy with appropriate technical detail for the middle school level. Deduct 5 points if key information is missing, 3 points if the detail level is inappropriate for middle schoolers. Give 10 points if comprehensive and age-appropriate.

checklist.title: Are interactive features implemented for learning enhancement?
checklist.description: Assess if the code includes interactive features that aid learning, such as element highlighting, pop-up information cards, filtering by element properties, or visual grouping by element categories. Deduct 5 points if no interactivity is implemented, 3 points if interactions are limited or buggy. Give 10 points for comprehensive, smooth, and educationally valuable interactions.

checklist.title: Is the periodic table visually coded for element categorization?
checklist.description: Check if the code implements visual distinctions (colors, patterns, borders) to differentiate element categories (metals, non-metals, metalloids, noble gases, etc.) and if a legend is provided to explain these visual codes. Deduct 5 points if categories are not visually distinguished, 3 points if visual coding is present but confusing or lacks a legend. Give 10 points for clear, consistent, and educational visual categorization.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common issues (such as various screen sizes, browser compatibility, loading failures for resources) and provides fallbacks or graceful degradation. Code with strong robustness should work across modern browsers and accommodate different viewport sizes. Give 10 points for comprehensive robustness with responsive design, 5 points if partially robust, and 0 points if serious compatibility issues exist.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the learning experience (e.g., 1. Element comparison tool 2. Quiz/game components 3. Interactive electron configuration visualizations 4. 3D element models). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Overlapping information displayed multiple times unnecessarily 2. Features unrelated to chemistry education 3. Excessive animations or effects that distract from learning. Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if redundant code interferes with the educational purpose.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review code organization (semantic HTML structure, separation of concerns with CSS/JavaScript), maintainability, and performance optimization. Deduct 5 points if non-semantic div/span elements dominate the structure; deduct 5 points if CSS/JS is not separated from HTML; deduct 5 points if the code contains unnecessary dependencies or unoptimized resources. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional educational design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the design follows educational interface principles: 1) Appropriate color contrast for readability (WCAG 2.1 AA compliance) 2) Clear visual hierarchy with primary information emphasized 3) Adequate white space for cognitive processing 4) Age-appropriate typography (sans-serif fonts, size â‰¥ 14px). Deduct 3 points for each readability issue, 5 points for poor contrast ratios, and 5 points for cluttered information architecture. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the interactive learning experience effective and age-appropriate?
checklist.description: Judge whether the interactive elements support middle school learning objectives: 1) Interactions teach scientific concepts rather than just entertain 2) Feedback is immediate and instructive 3) Progressive disclosure of complex information prevents cognitive overload. Deduct 5 points for interactions that don't support learning goals, 3 points for overly complex interactions beyond middle school comprehension, and 5 points for missing scaffolding in presenting information. The full score is 10 points.
